description_txt: stated on October 26, 2016 in an ad:

description_txt: stated on October 18, 2016 in a debate on WROC:
quote_txt: "The photonics bill that was sponsored in Congress and written, was written by Congressman Tom Reed, not Congresswoman Louise Slaughter."

description_txt: stated on October 20, 2016 in a news release:
quote_txt: Says Mike Coffman said two different things: "stop the deportations" in a Spanish-language debate and "you're going to be deported" in an English-language TV interview.

description_txt: stated on October 28, 2016 in an ad:
quote_txt: Says Russ Feingold said that with Obamacare, "we could keep our doctors and our plans, it was rated as the Lie of the Year."

description_txt: stated on November 2, 2016 in a rally in Tempe, Ariz.:
quote_txt: Says Donald Trump "says organized crime runs wild on reservations."

description_txt: stated on October 30, 2016 in a campaign speech.:
quote_txt: Says Nevadans will have a "double-digit hike in their Obamacare premiums for the year" and "10 of Nevada’s 16 counties will only have one Obamacare...exchange insurer"

description_txt: stated on November 3, 2016 in a speech in Jacksonville, Fla.:
quote_txt: "I have tremendous support from women."

description_txt: stated on November 1, 2016 in a posting on the Internet:

footer: By C. Eugene Emery Jr. • November 4, 2016

description_txt: stated on October 14, 2016 in a U.S. Senate debate:
quote_txt: "Prior to Obamacare here in Wisconsin, 95 percent of Wisconsinites were covered by insurance. After Obamacare, 95 percent of Wisconsinites were covered by insurance. It hasn’t had an impact."

description_txt: stated on November 2, 2016 in a rally in Pensacola, Fla.:
quote_txt: The media "never show crowds."

quote_txt: "In one Colorado hospital, 50 percent of newborns tested had marijuana in their system."

description_txt: stated on November 2, 2016 in a campaign speech:
quote_txt: Says Donald Trump "wants to undo marriage equality."

description_txt: stated on October 27, 2016 in a meeting with the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel editorial board.:
quote_txt: Says Ron Johnson "is benefiting from several super PACs, I am not."

description_txt: stated on October 29, 2016 in a private meeting with supporters:
quote_txt: "I had the longest judicial vacancy in the history of the United States."

description_txt: stated on October 27, 2016 in a campaign rally in Springfield, Ohio:
quote_txt: "Thousands of Americans have been killed by illegal immigrants."

description_txt: stated on October 28, 2016 in a commentary posted on Fox News:
quote_txt: "Students at the University of Texas in Austin have been advised not to wear cowboy boots or cowboy hats on Halloween."

description_txt: stated on October 14, 2016 in a radio ad:
quote_txt: Says Russ Feingold "formed his own political group to pay himself and his staff millions."

description_txt: stated on October 19, 2016 in the third presidential debate:
quote_txt: In Chicago, which has the toughest gun laws in the United States, probably you could say by far, they have more gun violence than any other city.

quote_txt: Says Chris Koster "opposes right-to-work efforts because he has taken $8 million from ‘union bosses.’"

quote_txt: "Amendment 1 protects Florida seniors from scams and rip-offs."

description_txt: stated on October 31, 2016 in remarks in Cocoa Beach, Fla.:

description_txt: stated on October 10, 2016 in a radio ad:

description_txt: stated on October 26, 2016 in a radio ad:
quote_txt: Says Donald Trump and Ron Johnson "oppose a woman's right to choose and Johnson voted against the Violence Against Women Act."

quote_txt: Says Donald Trump "doesn't believe in equal pay."

description_txt: stated on November 1, 2016 in a speech:
quote_txt: "Wisconsin is one of several states where you can change your early ballot if you think you've made a mistake."

description_txt: stated on October 30, 2016 in a Tweet:

description_txt: stated on September 30, 2016 in a press release:
quote_txt: Chris Koster "opposed protecting the women of Missouri" because he "was one of only four senators to vote against" a bill ending the practice of making rape victims pay for their own rape kits.

description_txt: stated on September 29, 2016 in a press release:
quote_txt: Says Chris Koster "fell silent" as attorney general in pursuing a case against a free classified service accused of promoting prostitution after accepting "over $12,000 in campaign contributions' from people affiliated with the service."
